briefOverview: A revelation calls Thomas to preach while assuring divine care for his family and guidance in ministry.
summary: The Lord blesses Thomas for his faith and promises that his family, including his children, will one day believe and join him. Thomas is called to begin preaching immediately, declaring what has been revealed to Joseph Smith, and to labor earnestly in a field ready for harvest. God promises to open hearts, enable the establishment and strengthening of the church through Thomas, and provide for his family’s needs. He is counseled to be patient under afflictions, govern his home with meekness, and not to revile when reviled. The Lord designates him a “physician unto the church,” directs him to rely on the Comforter for direction, and urges continual prayer to avoid temptation. A final assurance affirms Christ’s presence if he remains faithful to the end.
externalContext: This revelation is addressed to Thomas B. Marsh, an early convert in the first year of the Church of Christ (later known as The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints), during a period when new converts were frequently commissioned to preach soon after baptism. Early Latter-day Saint missionary work often involved brief separations from family as members traveled locally through the northeastern United States. The instruction about preparing people for gathering reflects a broader early-1830s Latter-day Saint emphasis on covenantal gathering to church centers, which would soon include Ohio and later Missouri. Promises of divine provision for families were important in a frontier economy where absence of a breadwinner could be risky.
externalReferences: Harvest and sickle imagery aligns with biblical depictions of urgent, end-time gathering and judgment (Joel 3:13; Revelation 14:15–16). The statement “the laborer is worthy of his hire” echoes Jesus’s instruction to missionaries (Luke 10:7; cf. Matthew 10:10). The promise of guidance by “the Comforter” reflects Jesus’s teaching about the Holy Spirit directing and instructing disciples (John 14:26), and the charge to “pray always” to avoid temptation parallels Jesus’s counsel in Gethsemane (Luke 22:40). Christ’s assurance of presence to a faithful servant resonates with the Great Commission’s “I am with you always” (Matthew 28:20) and the call to be faithful unto the end (Revelation 2:10).
practicalQuestions: How can I balance devotion to family with calls to serve beyond home responsibilities?
What does it look like for me to “thrust in [my] sickle with all [my] soul” in my present context?
How can I practice patience and avoid reviling when I am criticized or opposed?
In what ways can I be a “physician” within my faith community—helping to heal, strengthen, and stabilize others?
What habits will help me to “pray always” so I avoid temptation and stay spiritually responsive?
Where do I need to trust God to open hearts and provide for my household while I serve?
uncertainAreas: The phrase “physician unto the church, but not unto the world” could be metaphorical (spiritual healer) or related to personal skills; the text does not specify. The scope of “establish a church by your hand” is unclear (a local branch vs. broader founding). The unique wording “field which is white already to be burned” blends harvest and judgment imagery; the exact nuance is not fully explicit.
